SectionNotes: This chapter outlines the Company’s procedures for selecting, evaluating, and monitoring Contractors to ensure they meet the Company's HSQE (Health, Safety, Quality, Environment) performance requirements and comply with applicable standards and expectations.

Objectives: Ensure the proper selection and management of Contractors according to Company requirements.
Establish a consistent evaluation process for Contractor performance, safety, and quality compliance.
Maintain oversight and documentation of all Contractor activities affecting Company operations.

Details: Contractors must be evaluated before engagement and periodically thereafter, based on their performance and compliance with Company standards.
Evaluation reports are submitted to the Office for review and approval.
Appendix 1 includes a flowchart outlining the decision-making process for Contractor deployment.
Contractors are required to implement a system with measurable HSQE targets and key performance indicators (KPIs).
• LTIF/TRCF – Lost Time Injury Frequency / Total Recordable Case Frequency.
Contractors must maintain records and provide evidence of meeting or improving these targets.
The Company encourages Contractors to adopt continuous improvement initiatives in safety, environmental, and operational performance.
Periodic performance reviews help identify areas for development or corrective actions.
Contractor performance directly impacts the Company’s overall safety and environmental performance ratings.

Questions.QuestionText: 1. What is the main objective of Contractor Management within the Company?
Options: A. To reduce office paperwork
B. To ensure contractors are properly selected, evaluated, and monitored in line with Company standards
C. To outsource all shipboard maintenance tasks
D. To minimize the number of active contractors
Questions.Reason: Contractor Management ensures that all contracted parties meet the Company’s safety, quality, and environmental standards before and during engagement.

Options: A. Only after a contract ends
B. Before engagement and periodically thereafter as required
C. Once every five years
D. Only if a problem occurs onboard
Questions.Reason: Contractors must be evaluated both prior to engagement and periodically to ensure continued compliance and satisfactory performance.

Questions.QuestionText: 3. What is the purpose of the flowchart in Appendix 1?
Options: A. To describe shipboard emergency procedures
B. To illustrate the decision-making process for contractor deployment
C. To list all approved contractors
D. To record LTIF and TRCF data
Questions.Reason: The flowchart outlines the steps for evaluating and deciding on contractor deployment in compliance with Company standards.

Questions.QuestionText: 4. Which of the following performance metrics may Contractors be required to monitor?
Options: A. LTIF/TRCF, occupational health, environmental, and energy efficiency performance
B. Crew satisfaction and morale levels
C. Onboard food consumption rates
D. Voyage profit margins
Questions.Reason: Contractors must monitor measurable HSQE indicators such as LTIF/TRCF, occupational health, environmental, and energy performance.

Questions.QuestionText: 5. What must the Contractor provide to demonstrate compliance with performance targets?
Options: A. Verbal confirmation only
B. Records and evidence of meeting measurable HSQE targets
C. Copies of financial invoices
D. Crew evaluation reports
Questions.Reason: Contractors must maintain and present documented evidence demonstrating compliance with measurable HSQE targets.

Questions.QuestionText: 6. Why does the Company encourage continuous improvement among Contractors?
Options: A. To enhance overall Company HSQE performance and ensure safe, efficient operations
B. To reduce the number of contracts issued annually
C. To minimize reporting obligations
D. To eliminate contractor performance evaluations
Questions.Reason: Continuous improvement from Contractors supports the Company’s broader goals of improved safety, quality, and environmental performance.
